comments.commentBody: Or perhaps I realize the intent of the question and strategically answer the question in a particular way to effect the outcome I desire? Generally it isn't charitable to imply that someone else doesn't understand what they are doing.
And yet, choosing between Trump and a Neocon is precisely what American voters are being asked to do.  No wonder so many thinking voters are simply horrified at the choice.

"The author is a co-founder of the Project for a New American Century - that cabal of chickenhawks who brought us the Iraq invasion ..."

Thanks for outing this "opinion" for the advocacy of vested interests that is really is! A real service to readers to know from whom and from what bias point these things are emanating from! (And sadly, this not a unique case...)

One of the most pernicious aspects of this whole trend of "disguised content" and analysis, is the blurring of the line between honestly exploring ideas or presenting personal opinions and cloaking partisan points of view to pass off as objective!

This bad for "journalism," bad for the vital truth-telling function of the news and the news media, and bad for respect for "authoritative" news-people and sources of info! It's a key reason that many real news-seekers are turned off from our formerly-respected sources of news and info.

In a sick climate like that, the most absurd, illogical, and blatantly nonfactual 'info' gets strewn all over the media (and especially internet and social media!), and all sorts of fakers, double-talkers and outright liars get credibility they don't serve in their absurd statements and positions!

My thoughts exactly. He uses the term "Republican foreign policy veterans like me" as though it doesn't automatically invalidate anything else he says. I am consistently amazed at how these discredited neocons are trotted out as "foreign policy experts." Do they think people have collective amnesia when it comes to the Bush 43 years?

Hard to imagine an op-ed equating Obama's foreign policy with Trump's - but I just read it, so I know that it actually exists. I guess we need to consider the source.

The author is a co-founder of the Project for a New American Century - that cabal of chickenhawks who brought us the Iraq invasion, and who would best serve their nation today by agreeing to either spend the rest of their lives in inconspicuous political exile or behind bars. Either would do - but I would prefer them behind bars.

Virtually everything bad that has happened to the Middle East since 9/11 is their responsibility. They took a region that was troubled yet stable, and made it infinitely more troubled and unstable. In the aftermath of that terrible day, they exponentially increased the number of Muslims interested in committing murder and mayhem, instead of reducing it. The blood of hundreds of thousands, if not millions, is literally on their hands.

For those you more interested in dollars and cents, they saddled this country with trillions in unnecessary debt.

Trump will likely prove a disaster as President, particularly in the foreign policy area - but it's not as if these chickenhawks represent a better alternative. The neocons are the textbook definition of doing stupid stuff - and yet they resolutely refuse to learn from their mistakes.

Having to choose between Trump and a neocons is like having to choose between cancer and Alzheimer's. Either way, you're screwed.

Nobody can  know for sure. Obama has read the 38 pages. Being that he has run on the platform of transparency, it should tell you the evidence is pretty damning for him to attempt to supress it. Even Bernie Sanders has refused to read the 38 pages, because he knows he can't run a campaign on transparency and refuse to disclose classified information to the public.
They built lots and lots of mosques and sent lots of money to educational institutions so that they would teach that islam is a religion of peace.

The Saudis supplied half of the oil consumed by the United States in the early 80's.  The U.S. was dependent on middle east oil until 10 or 15 years ago. If there was no oil in the middle east, the U.S. would have no interest in the region.
As noted here, it's bunk that Saudi Arabia is or ever was our ally.  What did they ever do for us? Name one thing, please.
Unwittingly? I seriously doubt it.

You bring up a very distrptive and disturbed question because all of them have a piece of the cake and come from the same establishment, in my point of view what is giving momentum to this bill is that the American oil cartel who contibuted to republican and democrat campaigns doesn't need the saudis anymore so it hasn't lobbied against it but Obama isn't on the ballot!

Obviously you have a short memory. Afghanistan was the one blamed for 9/11 and we carpet bombed their mountain ranges for a long time. Iraq was a strategic ploy of WMDs orchistrated by the Bush administration so that the son could finish daddy's legacy. The pathetic thing is that Iraq was the least of out worries, they had previously sold their chemical weapons to Syria to continue to float the crumbling empire. Let's not forget Sadam Hussain was found hiding underneath a farm house like a common rat.

Not to mention Osama bin Laden's family members being flown out of the country while all other flights are grounded, and far in advance of any announcement of blame on Al Queda or Bin Laden, who was finally caught and killed where? In Pakistan, in their special forces' back yard, and Saudia Arabia's closest Muslim ally... A child could connect the dots.
Maybe they were reading "My Pet Goat".
Good, most Americans don't support the Saudi dictatorship anyway.

Unfortunately you are right. Counter Terrorism is STILL terrorism. How are we any better for going to Iraq and invading their country, killing innocent people, then installing our own government. How is what we are doing to other countries any better than what is being done to us. We created ISIS by not staying out of the middle east. America is responsible for just as much if not more terrorism practiced under the guise of justice and freedom.
Obama would be unwise to veto this bill. Override imminent. Protecting unloyal "allies"? Trump 2016. Never forgive. Never forget.
But don't you know that climate change is what is causing islamist jihad?

Given their budget problems, the Saudis may well need to sell assets to pay for the 9/11 damages. Good that they're thinking of getting a head start. The next thing the West needs to do is address climate change and really cripple the terrorist economies by eliminating the need for their major money-earning export, oil.

I guess you forgot that Al Queda was born in Afghanistan and the thousands of bombs we dropped on them. Iraq was a completely separate lie about WMDs after the government had fear mongerd enough of the population into viewing anyone middle eastern or Muslim as a terrorist.

Wow! Not even close.

Super delegates were created after the 1968 Democratic National Convention specifically to make the composition of the Democratic Party's nominating convention less (not more) subject to control by party leaders and more (not less) responsive to the votes cast in primary elections.

The super delegate system has changed somewhat since then, but, even so, Mr. Sanders problem isn't with the super delegates. His problem is more basic; he simply didn't get the support of the majority of voters.
Bingo!
Then by your arguement there are plenty of Iraquis we terrorised with our fake war on WMDs.  How many died, over a million? You do the math. Counterterrorism is still terrorism.
uf they   dump the note's bomb them and steal their oil  . how bout dat

You need to understand that as a registered Democrat you are simply a customer of the Democratic Party, not a shareholder. Have you donated money to the party? Have you worked for down-ticket candidates? have you attended their dinners, cookouts, and get-out-the vote events? Those are the people who make a party.

The Superdelegates are the leaders, movers, and shakers of a political party; they're chosen by the other active members of the party who share their same values and principles. You get a voice--you are invited to express your opinion during the caucuses. Maine caucusers have great influence, but they can't expect the party to just turn the keys over to people who stay home during mid-terms, who vote for Republicans sometimes, or who embrace some spellbinder who doesn't embrace the party's principles. That all being said, in your caucus Sanders received 64% of the votes and got 68% of the committed delegates. The seven Maine Superdelegates represent just 22% of Maine's say on who receives the nomination.

Even were all 32 Maine delegates to be awarded by the caucus results, Sanders would receive just four more delegates more than he would receive if all seven Superdelegates support Clinton. Ignoring Superdelegates entirely, Clinton still leads Sanders by 283 delegates, with 835 still to be decided, requiring Sanders to capture 700 of those 835 votes just to tie. It doesn't appear that four extra Maine delegates is going to change the outcome.

I'm sorry but what happened in Nevada was simple. Sanders delegates didn't show up. They were hundreds short. Those are the facts. The others, a few dozen who couldn't be vetted, either didn't show up, weren't registered as Democrats by May 1 or hadn't presented information that could be verified. Several Clinton delegates were also disqualified.

The qualification committee was composed of an equal number of representatives from both campaigns.

The only hanky-panky is the obnoxious attempt by the Sanders campaign to essentially overturn the results of the caucus, which Clinton won.

Why is that ok?

It isn't.

It's exactly the tactic employed by Cruz to steal delegates earned by Trump.

Much as I despise Trump (and Cruz) there's nothing noble about trying to overturn the results of a popular vote OR a caucus (and those are grossly undemocratic).

Please do not talk about JFK if you're willing to overturn the results of popular primary elections and/or caucuses, can't take the time to learn state convention and party rules and overtake the will of the people who really did vote.

The 99% are not going to do well in a chaotic "revolution" in which a heavily armed dictator will in all likelihood prevail.

Work through the system. Make our democracy work. If you don't like the two party system, figure out how to start a viable third party. Otherwise join the Democratic Party and make it work for you.
NYT - pick the above comment. Says it all (thank you).

It matters how many delegates each State has.  Bernie can win a lot of States and still come up short.  He is now going about the business of attempting to destroy a Party he has recently joined.  He is not a Democrat; he is an Independent.  He carries a small State; he will not carry California.  He is collecting a lot of donor money which he has not used to help any other Democrat.  He is not a member of the "establishment", and thank God for that.  It is cringe making to think of him yelling at our allies.  The kids who think of him as a kindly grandfather who will put them through college for free are not going to vote in any numbers larger than they did in the mid-terms when their absence gave us a Republican House.  They stayed home in a snit, as they plan to do now.  When will these adolescents grow up?  Maybe they agree with that actress who said that electing Trump would serve us right.  The rich actress who lives in Westport, CT., a very rich enclave.  She is all about Bernie and the working classes.

But those delegates are coached and culled by DWS. The real delegate difference is some 200-300 the other ones are all lobbyists working for Bill and Hillary Clinton and the DNC--not for the real dems.

We're getting Clinton and Clinton. The division in the democratic party was created by Clinton. She does not represent the democratic party. And Trump is already ripping Clinton and Clinton apart! He has until november. Imagine.

Bernie Sanders just won another state!
Hillary Clinton has an almost insurmountable lead in delegates.

Bernie Sanders just won another state!
(repeat)
Demagoguery 101, chapter one, using the royal We.

It's the royal "We" for Trump.
It's about parasites for Bernie.
Otherwise it's reserved for pregnant women.

Apology to Mr. Wilde.
Sorry BC, but Sanders does refer to himself in the third person. Way too often for my taste.
Not sure why Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders refer to themselves in third person. What is that about.
Huh?

@Berniesanders is misleading his people! Is a Jum Jones, going down the rabbit hole;it's no return! 30  yet where have you been? This isn't the movie "weekend @ Bernie's! Be honest with your soon to be shell shock followers when they realize, you keep your job & insurance they pay, yet their out of work! Gather your stock & treasure & support @HillaryClinton. She don't need to be held in servitude by you? Be honest and forthright Sen. Sanders!
The predictions have been that she'd win every state.  If you go back far enough, the predictions were by a large margin to boot.  Not sure what elections you've been following.
As for  Kentucky—if Bernie wins, another triumph for The Revolution!  If Hillary wins, another predictable victory in a "conservative" state.
